Name.BusinessNameLine1: AMERICAN LUNG ASSOCIATION OF THE MIDLAND

IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: TO FIGHT LUNG DISEASE AND PROMOTE LUNG HEALTH.
IRS990.MissionDescription: THE mission of the AMERICAN LUNG ASSOCIATION OF THE MIDLAND STATES IS to save lives by improving lung health and preventing lung disease.
IRS990.Description: LUNG DISEASE - DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR CHILDREN AND ADULTS WITH ASTHMA; DEVELOPMENT OF EDUCATIONal programs TO PREVENT LUNG DISEASE; DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PROGRAMS DEALING WITH LUNG CANCER, COPD, AND TUBERCULOSIS.

Activity2.Description: RESEARCH - COFUNDING OF ASTHMA CLINICAL RESEARCH CENTER AND VARIOUS RESEARCH PROJECTS AT UNIVERSITIES THROUGHOUT KENTUCKY, MICHIGAN, OHIO, AND TENNESSEE REGARDING CURES FOR LUNG DISEASE.

Activity3.Description: TOBACCO CONTROL - DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF SCHOOL HEALTH PROGRAMS AND SMOKING CESSATION CLASSES, PRINTING AND DISTRIBUTION OF SMOKING CESSATION MANUALS AND LITERATURE, DEVELOPMENT OF POLICIES FOR NON-SMOKER'S RIGHTS.

ActivityOther.Description: COMMUNITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH - PARTNERSHIPS WITH COMMUNITY HEALTH AGENCIES, PREPARATION AND DISTRIBUTION OF EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS FOR THE PUBLIC AND INDUSTRY.

Form990ScheduleCPartIV.Explanation: THE AMERICAN LUNG ASSOCIATION OF THE MIDLAND STATES, INC. IS ENGAGED IN LOBBYING ACTIVITIES WITH REGARD TO STATE AND FEDERAL PUBLIC POLICY. THE SUBJECT AREAS OF LEGISLATION AND/OR REGULATIONS INCLUDE TOBACCO USE AND CONTROL, ALLOCATION OF STATE TOBACCO SETTLEMENT DOLLARS, THE CIGARETTE TAX, FEDERAL AIR QUALITY RULES, AND FDA REGULATION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS.

OtherAssets.Description: BENEFICIAL INTEREST IN CHARITABLE FOUNDATION TRUST
INVESTMENT IN ASSETS HELD BY OTHER

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: THE ASSOCIATION HOLDS ENDOWMENT FUNDS FOR SUPPORT OF ITS PROGRAMS AND OPERATIONS.

Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Identifier: Procedure for Monitoring Grants in the U.S.:
Form990ScheduleIPartIV.Explanation: Schedule I, Part I, Line 2: THE ORGNIZATION VERIFIES THAT THE INDIVIDUAL IS ELIGIBLE FOR THE ASSISTANCE AT LEAST ONCE PER YEAR.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE FORM 990 IS REVIEWED BY MEMBERS OF THE STAFF OF THE ORGANIZATION AS WELL AS BY MEMBERS OF THE Finance Committee and the BOARD BEFORE FILING.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THE BOARD MEETS ON A REGULAR BASIS AND ANY BOARD MEMBER THAT HAS EVEN THE Remotest CONFLICT OF INTEREST ABSTAINS ON ANY ISSUES WITH WHICH THEY MIGHT HAVE A CONFLICT.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The Board's Executive Committee does a formal review of the CEO on an annual basis and the Executive Committee sets the annual salary based on the localized compensation surveys by non-profits including BoardSource and the Ohio Association of Non-profit Organizations.

GeneralExplanation.Identifier: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: THESE POLICIES ARE AVAILABLE THROUGH THE ORGANIZATION'S WEBSITE.

The American Lung Association of the Midland States' mission is to save lives by improving lung health and preventing lung disease. Among our varied responsibilities, we: -Fund research into the causes, prevention, and cures of lung disease. -Advocate for policies that protect lung health, including fighting for healthy air. -Provide a broad array of health educational programs and services to support smoking cessation, help prevent lung disease, and to assist people with lung disease in better managing their condition. -Provide an array of learning opportunities and tools to develop regional volunteer and staff leaders. -Provide the public with the latest information on lung disease and local lung association activities through the American Lung Association of the Midland States' website, www.midlandlung.org. The program services of the American Lung Association of the Midland States can be broken down into three broad categories: research, advocacy, and health education. Research Funding research has been a cornerstone of the Lung Association's fight against lung disease for more than a century. In 2009-10, our donors again made it possible to fund high quality researchers seeking treatments and cures for an array of lung diseases from asthma to lung cancer. Through our affiliation with ALA National, our nationwide research awards and grants program fosters laboratory and patient-centered and social behavior research to prevent, treat, and hopefully find a cure for all lung diseases. The Lung Association's Asthma Clinical Research Centers network (ACRC) continues to contribute major improvements to asthma treatments through a network of clinical centers throughout the country including an ACRC at the Ohio State University in Columbus, Ohio. During the year, the ACRC produced a number of manuscripts and editorials that were published in esteemed journals such as the American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, the New England Journal of Medicine, and Chest. Advocacy Every year the Lung Association fights for legislation defending your right to breathe healthy air, free of pollution or tobacco smoke. In 2009-2010, our advocacy efforts again yielded important victories. Tobacco Control In December, 2009, our smoke-free advocates celebrated a great accomplishment as the Governor of Michigan signed into law statewide smoke-free legislation. As of May 1, 2010, smoking was prohibited in almost all indoor worksites. Michigan became the 28th state nationwide to take this important lung health step. Clean Air Our State of the Air 2010 Report acknowledged progress against air pollution in many areas but found that six out of ten Americans live in areas where air pollution levels endanger lives. This eleventh annual report also found that nearly every major city was still burdened by air pollution. Health Education Every year the American Lung Association of the Midland States is there to help people manage their lung disease, overcome their nicotine addiction, and live healthier lives. We are a trusted resource where the public can find information on myriad lung diseases, make treatment decisions, and get support and tools to manage their conditions or care for a loved one. Tobacco To help adult smokers quit, the American Lung Association offers Freedom from Smoking, widely recognized as the gold standard for smoking cessation classes. Freedom from Smoking is available as a group clinic, an online program, and a self-help book. We also have a teen smoking cessation program, Not-on-Tobacco, that is a user-friendly gateway for those looking for a tobacco cessation program. Lung Disease The long-term goal of the American Lung Association is to reduce the burden of lung disease on patients and their families. We do this as follows: -Taught adults and children how to control their asthma - Our asthma education programs strive to reduce illness due to asthma by helping adults and children learn the skills they need to avoid asthma triggers, manage their medications, communicate with their health care team, and more. Breathe Well, Live Well, our asthma management program for adults, was launched four years ago and continues to expand. Through our Open Airways for Schools Program thousands of children are able to better manage their asthma and miss fewer days of school. -Provided guidance for asthma-friendly schools - Asthma 123 supports children with asthma by providing a comprehensive framework for asthma management in schools, enabling them to stay healthy in school and ready to learn. The Lung Association provides capacity building assistance to local communities to ensure a sustainable, comprehensive approach to asthma management in schools. -Improved quality of life for people living with COPD - Better Breather Clubs, our longest-running educational intervention program, improve the quality of live for their members by providing education, resources, networking, and support. The Lung Association works constantly to refresh and standardize the program materials and to provide expert technical assistance to local offices that are managing clubs. -Connected patients and families with expert advice - In all of our programs and education materials, people with questions about lung health are referred to the American Lung Association's Lung Helpline (1-800-Lungusa). In 2009-10, the nurses and respiratory therapists who staff the helpline took over 30,000 calls on topics ranging from use of air cleaning devices to testing for tuberculosis. -In addition the Diversity Committee's role is to recognize, respect, and respond to the needs of the diverse cultures and communities throughout the entire service area of ALAMS through recruitment and education; program diversity and partnerships; advocacy; and research.
